argumentText:
Let $f(x),\; a<x<b$ be a real-valued, $n$-times differentiable function,
and let $a<x_0<b$ be a fixed base-point. We will show that for all
$x\neq x_0$ in the domain of the function, there exists a $\xi$,
strictly between $x_0$ and $x$ such that
$$f(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f^{(k)}(x_0)\, \frac{(x-x_0)^k}{k!}
+ f^{(n)}(\xi)\,\frac{(x-x_0)^n}{n!}.$$

Fix $x\neq x_0$ and let $R$ be the remainder defined by
$$f(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f^{(k)}(x_0)\, \frac{(x-x_0)^k}{k!} +
R\,\frac{(x-x_0)^n}{n!}.$$ Next, define
$$F(\xi) = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f^{(k)}(\xi)\, \frac{(x-\xi)^k}{k!} +
R\,\frac{(x-\xi)^n}{n!},\quad a<\xi<b.$$ We then have $$\begin{aligned}
F'(\xi) &= f'(\xi)+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1} \left(f^{(k+1)}(\xi)\, \frac{(x-\xi)^k}{k!}
   - f^{(k)}(\xi)\, \frac{(x-\xi)^{k-1}}{(k-1)!}\right)
- R\,\frac{(x-\xi)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}\\
&= f^{(n)}(\xi)\, \frac{(x-\xi)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}-
R\,\frac{(x-\xi)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!} \\
&=  \frac{(x-\xi)^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}\, ( f^{(n)}(\xi)-R),\end{aligned}$$
because the sum telescopes. Since, $F(\xi)$ is a differentiable
function, and since $F(x_0)=F(x)=f(x)$, Rolle’s Theorem imples that
there exists a $\xi$ lying strictly between $x_0$ and $x$ such that
$F'(\xi)=0$. It follows that $R=f^{(n)}(\xi)$, as was to be shown.
